title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress acknowledges the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with regulatory requirements. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is recognized as an effective advocate for small businesses, ensuring agency responsiveness and compliance with statutory obligations. The independence of the Office is deemed essential for its effectiveness. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration needs independence to advocate effectively for small businesses, sufficient resources for research on regulations' impact, and expertise to advise Congress and executive branch agencies. The purpose of the Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is to advocate effectively for small businesses, conduct research on regulations' impact, and provide expertise to advise Congress and executive branch agencies. The purposes of this Act are to ensure the Office of Advocacy's independence and financial resources to advocate for small businesses, report to Congress and the President on regulatory issues, and have a separate authorization for appropriations. The purpose of this Act is to ensure the Office of Advocacy's independence and financial resources to advocate for small businesses, report on regulatory issues to Congress and the President, and have a separate authorization for appropriations. Additionally, it aims to enhance the role of the Office as outlined in title 5, United States Code. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 32, establishing the Office of Advocacy. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of Advocacy, with the Chief Counsel appointed by the President and Senate. The Office of Advocacy, with the Chief Counsel appointed by the President and Senate, has specific requirements for appointment, employment restrictions, removal process, and appropriation requests. The primary functions of the Office are outlined. The Office of Advocacy, led by the Chief Counsel appointed by the President and Senate, has specific requirements for appointment, employment restrictions, removal process, and appropriation requests. The primary functions of the Office include examining the role of small businesses in the economy and assessing the effectiveness of Federal subsidy and assistance programs for small businesses. The Office of Advocacy focuses on general assistance programs for small businesses, analyzing government regulation impact, tax structure effects, financial market credit availability, and financial resource availability. The Office of Advocacy evaluates financial resource availability and recommends methods for delivering financial assistance to minority and women-owned enterprises, generating markets, providing business education, management assistance, and compliance with laws. They also assess Federal and private sector efforts, make recommendations to support the development of minority, women-owned, and small businesses. The Office of Advocacy evaluates financial resource availability, recommends methods for delivering financial assistance to minority and women-owned enterprises, and assesses Federal and private sector efforts to support the development of small businesses. They also recommend specific measures for creating an environment where all businesses can compete effectively, determine criteria for defining small businesses, and make recommendations on issues affecting small businesses. The Office of Advocacy serves as a focal point for receiving complaints, criticisms, and suggestions regarding small businesses' policies and activities. It also counsels small businesses on resolving issues with the Federal Government and develops proposals for improving government policies affecting small businesses. The Office of Advocacy represents small businesses' views before Federal agencies, enlists cooperation in disseminating information about government programs, and carries out responsibilities under title 5, United States Code. The Chief Counsel has staff powers without regard to civil service laws. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Advocacy has the authority to appoint and terminate personnel necessary for the office's duties, with the ability to set compensation without following certain regulations, but within specified limits. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Advocacy has the authority to appoint personnel and set compensation not exceeding the maximum rate for a GS-15 position. The Chief Counsel may also procure temporary services and consult with experts in various financial fields. The Office of Advocacy can appoint advisory boards, hold hearings, and receive administrative support from the Administrator. The Office of Advocacy is provided with office space, equipment, supplies, and communication facilities for its central and field office locations. The Chief Counsel can request information from federal agencies as needed. Annual reports are submitted to the President and the Committees on Small Business of the Senate and House of Representatives. The Chief Counsel may prepare and publish reports on agency compliance with title 5, United States Code. Reports must be submitted to the President and Congress before any other federal department or agency. Reports must be submitted to the President and Congress before any other federal department or agency. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Office to carry out this section. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed, and the incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration will continue in their position. The Senate passed the bill on November 5, 1999. Gary Sisco attested as Secretary.
